item.title: Hunt for certainty over Covid cases continues
item.description: Flurry of Covid data does not resolve debate around state of the pandemic in the UK.

item.title: Pregnant women urged to get jab as majority unvaccinated
item.description: Estimates suggest hundreds of thousands of pregnant women in England have not yet had the vaccine.

item.title: Covid: Up to one in four admitted to hospital for other reasons
item.description: The government says counting all patients who test positive is vital because of the impact on the NHS.

item.title: Drug deaths in Scotland reach new record level
item.description: The country continues to have the worst drug death rate in Europe, with a further 1,339 people dying last year.

item.title: Latitude festival-goers test positive for coronavirus
item.description: The 40,000 people a day Latitude festival is a Covid-19 restrictions test event for the government.

item.title: Covid vaccines have prevented 60,000 deaths in England - Jonathan Van-Tam
item.description: He says future lockdowns are less likely the more people, including 18-25-year olds, get vaccinated.

item.title: Club night drops NHS Covid pass requirement
item.description: It comes as the Lib Dems demand MPs debate their use in England amid concerns over discrimination.

item.title: Drug firm fined for huge price rise that hit NHS
item.description: Advanz pushed up the price of thyroid tablet packs more than 10-fold, says the competition watchdog.

item.title: Are middle-aged people more unhealthy than ever?
item.description: Why could the current cohort of 40-somethings be proving less healthy than previous generations?

item.title: Woman died in Cardiff home after waiting 'hours' for ambulance
item.description: Maria Whale's husband John questioned whether his wife would have lived if help had come sooner.

item.title: NHS England appoints first female chief executive
item.description: Amanda Pritchard to take over from Sir Simon Stevens on 1 August, describing it as a great honour.

item.title: Blood inquiry: Former health minister defends blood products advice on Aids
item.description: Infected blood scandal survivors have accused ministers of misleading the public in 1983.

item.title: Covid vaccines: Tourists head to the US to get vaccinated
item.description: Some tourists are spending thousands of dollars to travel to the US to get a coronavirus vaccine.

item.title: Concussion and sport: How the lives of ex-sportspeople have been affected by concussion
item.description: BBC Radio 5 Live speaks to former sportsmen and women and their families about how concussion has changed their lives.

item.title: Covid: Where and why is the US vaccine rollout slowing down?
item.description: Vaccinations in the US are slowing as infections rise - we've looked at where and why this is happening.

item.title: Covid: What happens when people no longer have to wear masks?
item.description: Face coverings became optional in many settings in England on Monday - what's the evidence for them?

item.title: Heatwaves: What do they do to the body and who is at risk?
item.description: What impact do high temperatures have on our bodies?

item.title: Covid-19 rules: How six countries fared after easing Covid rules
item.description: As England approaches an end to social contact laws, how have other countries managed?

item.title: Covid: Which children are being vaccinated and why?
item.description: Hundreds of thousands of children at higher risk from coronavirus infection will be offered a Covid vaccine in the UK.

item.title: Why you shouldn't get a second Covid jab too early
item.description: A government scientific advisor tells Newsbeat why four weeks is too soon between Covid jabs.

item.title: Beta coronavirus variant: What is the risk?
item.description: There are fears that this version of coronavirus, first identified in South Africa, is

item.title: Covid rules: How can the clinically vulnerable stay safe?
item.description: As social-distancing and other Covid rules end in England, how can people who were shielding stay safe?

item.title: What are the rules and guidance for face masks and coverings from 19 July?
item.description: Masks are no longer compulsory in England, but remain necessary in Scotland and Wales.

item.title: How many cases in your area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Covid: What do under-30s need to know about the vaccine?
item.description: All over-18s can now get the Covid jab, but the government has criticised take-up among young people.

item.title: What are the Delta, Gamma, Beta and Alpha Covid variants?
item.description: UK coronavirus cases are rising due to a variant first identified in India that spreads more easily.

item.title: Covid rules: What has changed?
item.description: Major changes to lockdown rules have taken effect in England and Scotland, but some restrictions remain.

item.title: Covid: What's the advice for pregnant women and those who haven't had the jab?
item.description: Doctors and midwives are seeing a rise in unprotected pregnant women in hospital with Covid.

item.title: How do we know Covid vaccines are safe?
item.description: Busting myths and explaining the facts around vaccines.

item.title: Coronavirus: What it does to the body
item.description: What is it like to have the coronavirus, how will it affect you and how is it treated?

item.title: Support bubbles: How do they work and who is in yours?
item.description: Some people across the UK have been able to form "support bubbles" or "extended households".

item.title: How to get a Covid test
item.description: Everyone in England and Scotland is being encouraged to take rapid coronavirus tests regularly.

item.title: All you need to know on the coronavirus
item.description: A new cough, fever and change in smell or taste are the key symptoms that mean you may have coronavirus.

item.title: Coronavirus: Intensive care and other key terms explained
item.description: Use our tool to check the meaning of key words and phrases associated with the Covid-19 outbreak.

item.title: Coronavirus: What is the risk to men over 50?
item.description: While most people will have mild symptoms and recover quickly, some are more prone to getting sick.

item.title: Coronavirus: Do face masks actually work?
item.description: With face masks in high demand, we look at whether they really can protect people from the virus.

item.title: Covid: Professor Jonathan Van-Tam answers your questions
item.description: The deputy chief medical officer answers a range of questions about Covid from young audience members.

item.title: Dad builds robotic exoskeleton to help son walk
item.description: The French robotics engineer says he was inspired to build the suit after his son asked him to.

item.title: Brazil: Why are so many pregnant women dying from Covid?
item.description: One in five women that died from coronavirus in Brazil did not have access to an intensive care unit.

item.title: Michael Gove on vaccine passports at events with big crowds
item.description: People should be “confident” those attending large-scale events are “less likely to be carriers of the virus”, the Cabinet Office Minister says.

item.title: Boris Johnson on Covid infection rates falling for six days
item.description: The prime minister urges people not to “run away with premature conclusions” amid a fall in positive test numbers.
